head.title: 'Hidden Epidemic' Has No Basis in Fact

hedline.hl1: 'Hidden Epidemic' Has No Basis in Fact

abstract.p: Paul L Sterne letter responds to Sylvia Keller's August 13 article on dangers from cell phones and cell phone towers (S)

block.p: In response to Sylvia Keller's letter [''Just How Safe Is 'Wireless' Pollution?'' Aug. 13]: Based on 1998 data, the federal government recently increased the average life expectancy of an American male or female by two years. In response to Sylvia Keller's letter [''Just How Safe Is 'Wireless' Pollution?'' Aug. 13]: Based on 1998 data, the federal government recently increased the average life expectancy of an American male or female by two years. The population that is experiencing this increase in life expectancy is the first generation to be exposed to radio waves.

If the massive amount of radio waves that course through our bodies each day -- whether related to AM, FM, citizen's band, short wave, television, satellite transmissions, microwave transmissions, air traffic control radar beacons or cellular phones -- were the cause of health problems, their effect would have been visible in this large statistical sample. So talk of a ''hidden epidemic'' related to electro-magnetic radiation has no basis in fact, shows a lack of understanding of quantum physics and serves to distort the public debate on the cost-effective deployment of cellular technology.
